subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] new course for MemRise; new decks for ANKI
msgSnippet: Hi Ben, I take a look and try to send you something. And I ll take a look at that letter/key -- it may be that I need to upload a newer version of the font.
messageBody:
Hi Ben,
 
I take a look and try to send you something. And I'll take a look at that letter/key -- it may be that I need to upload a newer version of the font.
 
I'll reply later.
 
Be Well,
 
Scott
 
 
<<<< Scott Ellsworth -- phone 415-621-6148 >>>>
 
 
----- Original message -----
From: "Ben Logan trybloganatgmail@... [Read_Alphabet]" <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com>
To: "Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com" <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com>
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] new course for MemRise; new decks for ANKI
Date: Wed, 30 Sep 2015 18:23:02 +0000 (UTC)
 
 


Scott,
 
I forgot to ask something:  do you have longer passages written in Suave QS?  If not, I would like if I gave you--say--a page of all that on occasion for review.  I just want to make sure I'm going in the right direction.
 
Ben
 
 
On Wednesday, September 30, 2015 1:23 PM, "Ben Logan trybloganatgmail@... [Read_Alphabet]" <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
 
 
 
 
Scott,
 
Alright!  Well, right there you've given me plenty!  I will almost certainly want to pepper this discussion group with questions for you, if you don't mind.
 
One question is, what software did you use for creating or modifying the fonts?
 
Another,  well that special uppercase key ("pipe") is not mapped to the "awe" letter.  It's just pipe.  Now, really, I could probably go a long time without it.
 
Yes, I agree with you about the half letters and the ligatures.  Kerining does not sound like fun!  
 
This Yahoo site comes at a good place for me.  King Plus Monospace is a very good font for learning Junior QS (section I of the manual).   Now, I believe I'll switch to Suave for Section II (your script is great with readable abbreviations) and perhaps Junior or Jerome for Section III (where I can at least simulate written QS).
 
Sincerely,
 
Ben
 
 
On Tuesday, September 29, 2015 7:24 PM, "Scott Ellsworth scott@... [Read_Alphabet]" <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
 
 
 
 
Hello Ben,
 
I'm glad you like the Suave font. I created it to serve my own needs and preferences, and then thought I should share it. It doesn't seem to work perfectly with every version of every program, but it's the best I could manage with my limited knowledge and without a fancier font-editing program. Actually, all the full letters are present, though not all of them are mapped to the keyboard. The "awe" letter is located on the key where the "|" resides -- that's the same key I used for the accent mark, but the "awe" is uppercase (using the Shift key). This sound does not exist in my pronunciation, so I wanted to keep it out of the way, off to the side. But I kept it on the keyboard in case I might need it for some reason. The other letters you can find and input with the character map. So in LibreOffice, Insert > Special Character (shortcut: Alt-I, P). You'll see the X's, the degree sign, the euro sign, etc. To get some of those more quickly, you can try using Autocorrect and perhaps macros. (I personally use Autocorrect to obtain an accented "i" since that letter doesn't always line up right with an accent mark.)
 
I didn't include the half-letters because it seemed to me that they would be a lot of extra work to keep track of when typing. They would also add a tremendous amount of work with creating new "kerning pairs," so that they would line up properly with other letters. I tried to optimize the font for easy typing, while in my handwriting I use all the features of Senior Quikscript. So this ended up being a bit of a compromise: Junior Quikscript seems better suited to typing; but at the same time, I got used to how the letters neatly nest together in handwriting, so I created hundreds of kerning pairs in the font so that would happen at least most of the time.
 
I personally have no experience with conversion utilities. I was curious about Adapt-It but never got around to trying it out. 
 
Enjoy,
 
Scott
 
 
<<<< Scott Ellsworth -- phone 415-621-6148 >>>>
 
 
----- Original message -----
From: "trybloganatgmail@... [Read_Alphabet]" <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com>
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] new course for MemRise; new decks for ANKI
Date: 29 Sep 2015 11:49:50 -0700
Yes, thank you.  I myself don't understand the conflict with Shavian Script.  It is attractive, but it does not have all the dips and swoops that make QuickScript easier (in my mind) to read and write.  But, what do I know?
 
I've looking at the several fonts available at the site.  Each one has particular strengths.  Suave (swxv) appears to meet my needs in an American font.  However, there does not appear to be an "aw" letter, unless "ox" in American English is close enough.
 
Everyone has their personal reasons for preferring one or another.  I might try to do without half letters and with fewer ligatures for the time being, as Ellsworth recommends.  And eventually, I'll see what happens to my reading ability.  If you know how to contact him, please let me know.  I've got questions.
 
For some perhaps minor reason, Suave--out of all fonts I've looked at--appears to look most like phonetic English if converted to Ariel or whatever.  A little minor search and replaces in LibreOffice, and I'm pretty good to go.
 
One other item:  Is it possible to find the source code for that wonderful QS_Converter?  Are the Perl Scripts in another folder related?  This brings up an interesting question for me.  How well could it convert from QS back to English?   What percentage of errors would I find?

<di=
v style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;"><div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;"><div s=
tyle=3D"line-height: 1.22em;"><div> </div>
<div style=3D"line-height: =
1.22em;"><div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;"><div style=3D"line-height: 1.2=
2em;"><div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;"> </div>
<div style=3D"line-h=
eight: 1.22em;">Hello Ben,<br></div>
<div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;">&n=
bsp;</div>
<div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;">I'm glad you like the Suave =
font. I created it to serve my own needs and preferences, and then thought =
I should share it. It doesn't seem to work perfectly with every version of =
every program, but it's the best I could manage with my limited knowledge a=
nd without a fancier font-editing program. Actually, all the full letters a=
re present, though not all of them are mapped to the keyboard. The "awe" le=
tter is located on the key where the "|" resides -- that's the same key I u=
sed for the accent mark, but the "awe" is uppercase (using the Shift key). =
This sound does not exist in my pronunciation, so I wanted to keep it out o=
f the way, off to the side. But I kept it on the keyboard in case I might  =
need it for some reason. The other letters you can find and input with the =
character map. So in LibreOffice, Insert > Special Character (shortcut: =
Alt-I, P). You'll see the X's, the degree sign, the euro sign, etc. To get =
some of those more quickly, you can try using Autocorrect and perhaps macro=
s. (I personally use Autocorrect to obtain an accented "i" since that lette=
r doesn't always line up right with an accent mark.)<br></div>
<div style=
=3D"line-height: 1.22em;"> </div>
<div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;">=
I didn't include the half-letters because it seemed to me that they would b=
e a lot of extra work to keep track of when typing. They would also add a t=
remendous amount of work with creating new "kerning pairs," so that they wo=
uld line up properly with other letters. I tried to optimize the font for e=
asy typing, while in my handwriting I  use all the features of Senior Quiks=
cript. So this ended up being a bit of a compromise: Junior Quikscript seem=
s better suited to typing; but at the same time, I got used to how the lett=
ers neatly nest together in handwriting, so I created hundreds of kerning p=
airs in the font so that would happen at least most of the time.<br></div>
=
<div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;"> </div>
<div style=3D"line-height:=
 1.22em;">I personally have no experience with conversion utilities. I was =
curious about Adapt-It but never got around to trying it out. <br></di=
v>
<div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;"> </div>
<div style=3D"line-heig=
ht: 1.22em;">Enjoy,<br></div>
<div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;"> </d=
iv>
<div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;">Scott<br></div>

=
<div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;">Yes, thank you.  I myself don't un=
derstand the conflict with Shavian Script.  It is attractive, but it d=
oes not have all the dips and swoops that make QuickScript easier (in my mi=
nd) to read and write.  But, what do I know?<br></div>
<div style=3D"f=
ont-family: Arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-heig=
ht: 1.22em;"><div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;"><div style=3D"font-family:=
 Georgia; line-height: 1.22em;"><div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;"> <=
/div>
<div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;">I've looking at the several fonts=
 available at the site.  Each one has particular strengths.  Suav=
e (swxv) appears to meet my needs in an American font.  However, there=
 does not appear to be an "aw" letter, unless "ox" in American English is c=
lose enough.<br></div>
<div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;"> </div>
<di=
v style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;">Everyone has their personal reasons for pr=
eferring one or another.  I might try to do without half letters and w=
ith fewer ligatures for the time being, as Ellsworth recommends.  And =
eventually, I'll see what happens to my reading ability.  If you know =
how to contact him, please let me know.  I've got questions.<br></div>=

<div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;"> </div>
<div style=3D"line-height=
: 1.22em;">For some perhaps minor reason, Suave--out of all fonts I've look=
ed at--appears to look most like phonetic English if converted to Ariel or =
whatever.  A little minor search and replaces in LibreOffice, and I'm =
pretty good to go.<br></div>
<div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;"> </di=
v>
<div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;">One other item:  Is it possible=
 to find the source code for that wonderful QS_Converter?  Are the Per=
l Scripts in another folder related?  This brings up an interesting qu=
estion for me.  How well could it convert from QS back to English? &nb=
sp; What percentage of errors would I find?<br></div>
</div>
</div>
